titleStmt.title: Effects of the herbicide Irgarol 1051 on the transcriptome of hermatypic coral Acropora tenuis and its symbiotic dinoflagellates

analytic.title: Effects of the herbicide Irgarol 1051 on the transcriptome of hermatypic coral Acropora tenuis and its symbiotic dinoflagellates

biblStruct.note: Received 21 December 2020 Received in revised form 9 March 2021 Accepted 13 March 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Acropora tenuis Symbiotic dinoflagellates Coral bleaching Transcriptome analysis Irgarol 1051 RNA sequencing

abstract.p: Hermatypic corals face multiple threats, including PSII herbicides and warming. • Irgarol, a PSII herbicide, is used as a new generation antifouling agent. • We identified~150 DEGs in corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates exposed to Irgarol. • Our data indicate a wide variety of disturbances in gene expression in both biota. • Our results suggest the potential bleaching molecular mechanisms in both biota.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Coral reefs play important ecological roles, such as providing habitat and spawning grounds for a wide range of marine animals, and they are among the most productive and biodiverse ecosystems on Earth (Burke et al., 2011). However, the global decline in hermatypic corals in tropical and subtropical regions is a growing concern, and it may have substantial negative effects on marine ecosystems (Normile, 2016). The recent review of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) indicated that coral reefs would almost completely disappear with a 2°C rise in temperature due to global warming and that only 10%-30% of existing reefs will survive with an increase of 1.5°C (Tollefson, 2018). In addition to the increase in seawater temperature as a result of climate change, coral reefs have been globally affected by various environmental phenomena, such as ocean acidification, diseases, overfishing, coastal development, and environmental pollutants (Burke et al., 2011;Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007;Morrison et al., 2019). The hermatypic corals host symbiotic dinoflagellates (Symbiodinium and related genera) within individual cells in their inner gastrodermal layer (Oakley and Davy, 2018;LaJeunesse et al., 2018). These environmental stressors may disrupt the symbiotic relationships between corals and photosynthetic dinoflagellates, inducing severe coral bleaching (Burke et al., 2011;Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007;Morrison et al., 2019;Normile, 2016). For example, in response to elevated temperature, the host coral initiates a complex suite of responses, including an elevation in host endogenous oxidative stress and induction of the host innate immune response against the symbiotic dinoflagellates, leading to host cell apoptosis (Oakley and Davy, 2018).

Spontaneous colonisation of submerged surfaces by various aquatic organisms, generally called biofouling, has been presenting serious economic and environmental costs and posing health risks to a wide range of industrial activities, from shipping transport to offshore structures, water purification plants, and cooling power plants (Silva et al., 2019). Owing to the global ban imposed on the use of antifouling paints containing tributyltin (TBT) in 2008, an alternative copper-dominated agent has again become the predominant antifouling biocide (Dafforn et al., 2011). Several algae possess copper tolerance; most copperdominated antifouling biocides contain booster biocides to prevent algal attachment (Dafforn et al., 2011;Manzo et al., 2006). Irgarol 1051 (hereinafter referred to as Irgarol) is one of the widely used booster agents mixed with copper-dominated antifouling biocides (Manzo et al., 2006). It acts by inhibiting photosynthetic electron transport in chloroplasts and is used to control redundant algal growth on submerged structures (Jones and Kerswell, 2003;Oettmeier, 1999). Irgarol contamination has been reported in coastal marine ecosystems, including coral reefs and the adjacent areas, worldwide (Ansanelli et al., 2017;Basheer et al., 2002;Carbery et al., 2006;Diniz et al., 2014;Knutson et al., 2012;Lam et al., 2005;Manzo et al., 2014;Rodríguez et al., 2011;Saleh et al., 2016;Sheikh et al., 2009Sheikh et al., , 2016. Previous toxicity studies have demonstrated that exposure to Irgarol at environmentally relevant concentrations of <1 μg/L decreased the maximum effective quantum yield (ΔF/F m ′), which is an indicator of photosynthetic efficiency under light conditions, in symbiotic dinoflagellates (Jones and Kerswell, 2003;Owen et al., 2002). In our previous study, we observed a reduction in the ΔF/F m ′ in symbiotic dinoflagellates of the coral Acropora tenuis after 7 d of exposure to 20 and 200 ng/L Irgarol, which are ecologically relevant concentrations in tropical to subtropical coastal seawaters (Kamei et al., 2020). In addition, our previous study demonstrated that compromising the electron accumulation function of quinones Q A and Q B in photosystem II (PSII) leads to bleaching and changes in coral colour (Takeuchi et al., 2020). These results suggest that Irgarol directly affects the photosynthetic efficiency of the photosynthetic dinoflagellate symbionts within corals.

In contrast to their effects on photosynthetic efficiency, such as ΔF/ F m ′ reduction and colour change, the molecular effects of herbicides (including Irgarol) on corals and symbionts are not well understood.

Previously, we found that the gene expression of molecular chaperones, such as heat shock protein (HSP) 90 (symHSP90) and 70 (symHSP70), in symbiotic dinoflagellates was up-regulated after 7 d of exposure to Irgarol at 20 and 200 ng/L, whereas the expression of A. tenuis HSP90 (atHSP90) was not affected by Irgarol at these concentrations (Kamei et al., 2020). Moreover, the expression of atHSP90 was downregulated in corals after 7 d of exposure to Irgarol at 1 and 10 μg/L, which resulted in coral bleaching (Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018). These results suggest that HSPs in corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates are involved in bleaching. However, details of the molecular mechanism through which PSII herbicides such as Irgarol induce coral bleaching in host corals and their symbiotic dinoflagellates have not been fully elucidated.

Although whole genome sequencing of hermatypic coral (Shinzato et al., 2011) and its symbiotic dinoflagellates (Shoguchi et al., 2013) has been performed, comprehensive gene expression has not yet been examined under PSII herbicide-induced coral bleaching. Moreover, a recent review demonstrated that some genes, including HSP, metabolism-, oxidative stress-, immune response-, ion transport-, and structurerelated genes, are emerging as powerful diagnostic tools for identifying and characterising coral stress (Louis et al., 2017).

Therefore, in this study, we investigated the physiological responses of the coral A. tenuis, a common hermatypic coral species in the Indo-Pacific region, and its dinoflagellate symbionts to Irgarol as well as the molecular mechanisms underlying these responses (Hoeksema and Cairns, 2020). We initially assessed the body colour of corals after 7 d of exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol. We further analysed whether the transcriptomic profiles of the corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates changed after 7 d of exposure to Irgarol by RNA-sequencing (RNA-Seq). We performed Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway enrichment analyses to understand the potential molecular mechanisms underlying the coralbleaching effect of Irgarol. Our study provides novel insights into the potential molecular mechanisms underlying the bleaching effect of Irgarol on corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates and contributes to our understanding of the effects of the new generation of antifouling biocides on the coral reefs in tropical coastal regions.

div.head: Test chemicals
div.p: Two grams of Irgarol (Cas No.: 28159-98-0, purity >99%; FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, Osaka, Japan) was dissolved in 1 L of acetone (purity >99%; FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation) to prepare a stock solution, which was stored at 4°C until use. Irgarol test solutions were prepared by serially diluting the stock solution with artificial seawater (hereinafter referred to as seawater) in 34 psu containing LIVE sea salt (Delphis Inc., Itami, Hyogo, Japan) as previously described (Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018). Artificial seawater was used because the coastal waters in western Japan (including Ehime and Okinawa prefectures) have been reported to contain various contaminants, including Irgarol (Murai et al., 2005;Okamura et al., 2003;Sheikh et al., 2009;Takeuchi et al., 2004). The final solvent concentration was adjusted to 0.001% v/v (Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018).

div.head: Laboratory exposure experiments
div.p: Laboratory exposure experiments were conducted according to our previously reported method (Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018). Briefly, a colony of cultured A. tenuis was purchased from Uminotane Inc. (Yomitan, Okinawa, Japan) and acclimated in a 72 L aquarium in our laboratory. After 2 weeks of acclimation, the tip of each apical branch-like part (~10 mm in length) of the colony was cut, and then acclimation was continued for another 2 d in the same aquarium. Irgarol exposure concentrations were selected based on the findings of our previous studies (Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018). Corals (randomly selected for each treatment group; n = 8) were exposed to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol in glass Petri dishes (80 mL test solution) for 7 d. Control (seawater) and solvent control (0.001% acetone in seawater) groups were also prepared. During the 7 d exposure period, the total volume of the test solutions, including control and solvent controls, and Petri dishes were replaced every 48 h, and corals were maintained at 27.5°C under a 12:12 h (light: dark) photoperiod and illuminated using an LED light (50 μmol m −2 s −1 ). Hirayama et al. (2017) confirmed that the concentration of Irgarol that remained after 2 d was over 80% of the initial concentration in both 1 μg/L and 10 μg/L treatments. At the end of the 7 d exposure period, the whole fragment of corals (n = 8 per treatment group) was sampled, rapidly preserved in RNAlater solution (Qiagen, Tokyo, Japan), and stored at −80°C until analysis. The glass devices used in the experiment were washed and cleaned using acetone, hexane, HCl, tap water, and distilled water as described in our previous ecotoxicity experiments in invertebrates (Aono and Takeuchi, 2008;Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018;Kamei et al., 2020;Takeuchi et al., 2020).

div.head: Body colour analysis
div.p: During the 7 d exposure period, the body colour of the corals was analysed using a digital camera imaging system according to the method developed in our previous study (Hirayama et al., 2017). Briefly, photographs were taken daily at the same time (11:00-12:00 am), and the Nikon Electronic Format files, which are in Nikon's RAW file format, were used for analysing the RGB (R, red; G, green; B, blue) value. The range of the R, G, and B values was 0 (darkest) to 255 (brightest). White was indicated by R = G = B = 255 and black by R = G = B = 0. The analysed areas of the corals were converted to RGB values using Adobe Photoshop CC TM (Adobe Systems Incorporated, San Jose, CA, USA). The RGB values of the corals were corrected according to the red colour of the colour chart, and an increase in the RGB value indicated that the colour of coral changed due to bleaching (Hirayama et al., 2017).

The RGB values were statistically analysed using GraphPad Prism ver. 7.0 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA), and tested for normality using Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. Student's t-test was performed to determine differences between the control and solvent control groups. As no significant differences were detected, the solvent control groups were used in the subsequent analysis. Bartlett's test was used to assess all experimental data to test the assumption of homogeneity of variance among treatments. When the assumptions were met, the data were analysed using a parametric one-way analysis of variance, followed by Dunnett's multiple comparison tests (Dunnett, 1955). If there was heterogeneity, we used the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis test, followed by Dunn's multiple comparison test or Mann-Whitney U test with Bonferroni's adjustment (Glantz, 1992). Differences were considered significant at p < 0.05.

div.head: RNA extraction, and library preparation and sequencing
div.p: Coral samples were ground to a fine powder using a dry ice-chilled mortar and pestle before homogenisation with TissueLyser II (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany), and the total RNA was isolated from the homogenised samples using the RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen), as previously described (Ishibashi et al., 2018). RNA quality was determined using Agilent Bioanalyzer 2100 with the Agilent RNA 6000 Nano Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA). RNA samples with an RNA integrity number (RIN) of >6.8 were used in our subsequent analyses. Poly(A) + RNA was purified using the Oligotex-dT30 <Super> mRNA Purification Kit (Takara Bio Inc., Shiga, Japan). After RNA-oligo ligation at the fragmented mRNA ends, the firstand second-strand cDNA was synthesised, followed by PCR amplification, purification, and size selection (200 bp) using Ion Total RNA-Seq Kit v2 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The selected PCR products were used in emulsion PCR analysis (Ion OneTouch System and Ion PGM Template OT2 200 Kit; Thermo Fisher Scientific), followed by positive bead recovery, chip loading, and sequencing. Sequencing was performed using the Ion PGM system with Ion PGM Sequencing 200 Kit v2 and 318 v2 chip (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

div.head: Differentially expressed genes, gene ontology, pathway, and network analyses
div.p: The RNA-Seq data were demultiplexed, trimmed, aligned, and analysed using CLC Genomics Workbench 10.1.1 (Qiagen). Initially, the adapter sequence was removed, and then the reads were trimmed using Phred quality score 30 (base call accuracy: 99.9%) to obtain high-quality sequences. For de novo assembly, the reads were uploaded into CLC Genomics as FASTA files and assembled using default parameters. All assembled contigs were compared with A. tenuis and Symbiodinium sequences in the NCBI Acropora (https://www.ncbi.nlm. nih.gov/nuccore/?term=acropora) and Symbiodinium mRNA (https:// www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/?term=Symbiodinium) databases, respectively, for functional annotation using standalone Blastn (within the CLC Genomics tool). For gene expression analysis, the expression level of each gene in the solvent control and Irgarol-treated samples was calculated and normalised to reads per kilobase per million (RPKM) and fold change values. A two-fold change in the RPKM values of the corresponding transcripts between the control and Irgaroltreated groups was considered to indicate differential expression (Tominaga et al., 2019). For functional categorisation of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in the Irgarol-treated group, up-regulation and down-regulation were defined as the gene expression ratio of the exposed to control groups of >3 and <1/3, respectively (Tominaga et al., 2019).

The GO and KEGG pathway enrichment analyses were performed using the Search Tool for the Retrieval of Interacting Genes (STRING) database (https://string-db.org/) (Szklarczyk et al., 2017). The GO annotation results were categorised as biological process, cellular component, and molecular function, and significant processes (false discovery rate: FDR) were selected based on a corrected p-value of <0.05. To identify the hub genes, a protein-protein interaction (PPI) network of significant DEGs was constructed and analysed on STRING. We examined the clustering of protein interactions with high confidence scores (≥0.7) (Kaniewska et al., 2015).

div.head: Effect of Irgarol on coral colour
div.p: During the 7 d exposure period, coral colours were stable in the control, solvent control, and 1 μg/L Irgarol-treatment groups (Fig. 1A), and there were no significant differences in the red, green, and blue (RGB) values among these groups (Fig. 1B). In contrast, the RGB values of the 10 μg/L Irgarol-treatment group increased over time, with significant differences from day(s) 4 and/or 5 until the end of the experimental period compared with those of the solvent control group (Fig. 1B). By day 7, the mean RGB values of the 10 μg/L Irgarol-treatment group increased to approximately 130%-150% of the values of the solvent control group. The R value increased from 116.9 ± 12.0 (standard deviation) to 151.6 ± 13.3, the G value from 62.9 ± 9.6 to 93.0 ± 10.1, and the B value from 86.3 ± 11.7 to 125.0 ± 10.8 in the 10 μg/L Irgarol-treatment group during the experiment (Fig. 1A and B).

div.head: Differentially expressed genes in response to Irgarol exposure
div.p: RNA-Seq revealed 142 (100 up-and 42 down-regulated) and 109 (40 up-and 69 down-regulated) DEGs in corals after exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol, respectively. A comparison of these DEGs revealed that 58 genes, including green fluorescent protein (GFP), blue-lightsensing photoreceptor (cryptochrome: cry1), chromoprotein, caspase 8, and nuclear receptor (AmNR7), overlapped between the treatment groups (Tables S1 and S2).

In symbiotic dinoflagellates, the RNA-Seq analysis revealed 111 (97 up-and 14 down-regulated) and 116 (15 up-and 101 downregulated) DEGs after exposures to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol, respectively. A comparison of the DEGs showed that 55 genes, including lightharvesting protein-coding, photosystem II, heat shock proteins (i.e. HSP70 and HSP90), and ubiquitin-related genes, occurred in both the 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol-treatment groups (Tables S3 and S4).

div.head: GO, KEGG pathway, and network analyses
div.p: A gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) of DEGs was performed to identify GO terms and KEGG pathways affected by Irgarol in corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates. In the biological process analysis, DEGs involved in various metabolic/biosynthesis processes, transport (GO:0006810), cell death (GO:0008219), photosynthesis (GO:0015979), carbon fixation (GO:0015977), and other processes were significantly enriched in corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates treated with 1 or 10 μg/L Irgarol (Figs. 2, 3). In the GO cellular component (CC) analysis, several membrane terms, such as intercellular membrane-bounded organelle (GO:0043231) and cytoplasm (GO:0005737), and other terms were affected by both Irgarol treatments in both species (Figs. 2, 3). In the GO molecular function analysis, various binding terms, such as nucleic acid (GO:0003676) and cation (GO:0043169), and other functions in corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates were affected by the Irgarol treatments (Figs. 2, 3).

In corals, the KEGG pathway and protein interaction network analyses revealed the effects of 10 μg/L Irgarol on oxidative phosphorylation (pathway ID 190, false discovery rate [FDR] = 1.40E-10) and the metabolic pathway (pathway ID 1100, FDR = 0.00942), including the expression of ATP6, COX1, COX2, COX3, CYTB, ND1, ND2, ND3, ND4, and ND5; the transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) signalling pathway (pathway ID 4350, FDR = 0.0012), including the expression of Bmp2, Bmp8a, Gdf5, and Smad2; the adherens junction (pathway ID 4520, FDR = 0.0132), including the expression of Actb, Smad2, and Snai2; and apoptosis (pathway ID 4210, FDR = 0.0169), including the expression of Apaf1, Bcl2, and Casp8 (Table 1 and Fig. 4). Only the TGF-β signalling pathway (FDR = 0.00575), comprising v1g168041, v1g168498, and v1g194892, was affected by the 1 μg/L Irgarol treatment (Table 1 and Fig. S1).

In symbiotic dinoflagellates, the KEGG pathway and the protein interaction network analyses revealed that the 1 μg/L Irgarol treatment affected carbon fixation in photosynthetic organisms (pathway ID 710, FDR = 0.000267), metabolic pathways (pathway ID 1100, FDR = 0.00568), photosynthesis (pathway ID 195, FDR = 0.00668), and protein processing in the endoplasmic reticulum (pathway ID 4141, FDR = 0.0134) ( Table 2 and Fig. S2). Similarly, the 10 μg/L Irgarol Fig. 1. (A) Photographs and (B) red, green, and blue (RGB) values in Acropora tenuis exposed to 1 or 10 μg/L Irgarol for 7 d. Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation (n = 8 per treatment group). *, **, and *** denote a significant difference compared with the solvent control group at p < 0.05, p < 0.01, and p < 0.001, respectively. treatment affected these KEGG pathways and protein interaction networks, including protein processing in the endoplasmic reticulum (FDR = 0.00284), which includes HSP90_1, Thaps22432, Thaps269547, and HSP70; carbon fixation in photosynthetic organisms (FDR = 0.00453), which includes GAPD1, RBL, and gapC3; and photosynthesis (FDR = 0.00463), which includes PSBC, petB, and psbA (Table 2 and Fig. 5). Fig. 2. Gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis in Acropora tenuis. GO enrichment analysis of the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in Acropora tenuis exposed to (A) 1 μg/L or (B) 10 μg/L Irgarol for 7 d. Fig. 3. Gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis in symbiotic dinoflagellates. GO enrichment analysis of the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in symbiotic dinoflagellates exposed to (A) 1 μg/L or (B) 10 μg/L Irgarol for 7 d. The pathways indicated in bold are those in the protein-protein interaction network (Figs. 4 and S1). Fig. 4. Protein-protein interaction network of the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in Acropora tenuis exposed to 10 μg/L Irgarol for 7 d. Protein interactions were categorised according to their Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway classifications.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Irgarol 1051, which is currently used as a booster for new generation antifouling agents following the TBT ban, is a PSII herbicide that inhibits the chloroplast electron transport chain (Jones, 2005;Oettmeier, 1999;Takeuchi et al., 2020). Owing to the widespread distribution of Irgarol in coastal ecosystems (Ansanelli et al., 2017;Basheer et al., 2002;Carbery et al., 2006;Diniz et al., 2014;Knutson et al., 2012;Lam et al., 2005;Manzo et al., 2014;Rodríguez et al., 2011;Saleh et al., 2016;Sheikh et al., 2009Sheikh et al., , 2016, its potential hazards and risks to corals are of concern (Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018;Kamei et al., 2020;Takeuchi et al., 2020). Thus, in the present study, we assessed the body colour changes in A. tenuis, a common hermatypic coral species in the Indo-Pacific region (Hoeksema and Cairns, 2020), occurring during Irgarol exposure for 7 d. Analyses of the RGB values of corals revealed significant increases in these values in corals exposed to 10 μg/L Irgarol for 5 d (only the B value significantly increased on day 4), compared with those in the solvent control group. Similarly, our previous studies demonstrated a significant increase in the RGB values in A. tenuis exposed to 10 μg/L Irgarol for 5 d (Hirayama et al., 2017;Ishibashi et al., 2018). These results indicate that the body colour of corals shifted toward white (i.e. bleaching) following exposure to 10 μg/L Irgarol over 5 d.

Studies on molecular responses in corals have focused on coral responses to elevated temperatures more than those to the maximum average temperature in summer or ocean acidification (Kaniewska et al., 2015;Moya et al., 2012;Palumbi et al., 2014;Portune et al., 2010). The physiological impairment of the algal symbionts and their exclusion from host coral are primarily considered to be a result of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation by the host coral, the algal symbiotic dinoflagellates, or both, triggering a host-immune response related to host cell apoptosis (Oakley and Davy, 2018). However, the molecular mechanisms involved in bleaching induced by PSII herbicides, such as Irgarol, in corals and its symbiotic photosynthetic dinoflagellates are not yet fully understood, beyond observations that HSP expression is affected by Irgarol.

The present RNA-Seq analysis represents the first comparative transcriptomic analysis of A. tenuis and its symbiotic dinoflagellates during bleaching under different Irgarol concentrations. We identified 142 and 109 DEGs in corals after treatments with 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol, respectively, and 58 genes overlapped between the treatment groups; interestingly, GFP and cry1 were among these overlapping DEGs. Previous studies have demonstrated that the gene expression of fluorescent proteins (FPs), including GFP, is affected by high temperature treatments (32°C or 33°C), resulting in the down-regulation of GFP-homolog gene in A. millepora (Smith-Keune and Dove, 2007) and A. tenuis (Yuyama et al., 2011). Recently, Aihara et al. (2019) demonstrated that Symbiodinium has positive phototaxis mostly toward weak green light and negative phototaxis mostly toward strong purple-blue light. Therefore, this alga swims toward the chalice corals (Echinophyllia aspera), and not the light source, when corals emit green fluorescence (e.g. strong blue light) (Aihara et al., 2019). This suggests a critical role of GFP in the symbiosis between corals and algae (Aihara et al., 2019). These results indicate that the disruption of FP expression, including GFP, may negatively affect the coral-Symbiodinium symbiosis. Moreover, Levy et al. (2007) evaluated the expression patterns of crys (known as circadian clock-related molecules in the animal kingdom) in response to daylight (cry1 and cry2) and moonlight (cry2) in A. millepora. Their results suggested that cry1 and cry2 are potentially involved in coordinating the synchronous spawning of corals during a few nights each year. Further studies are necessary to clarify how cry1 affects the stress tolerance of corals, such as A. tenuis, under Irgarol exposure.

In the present study, the RNA-Seq analysis of symbiotic dinoflagellates revealed 111 and 116 DEGs after exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol, respectively, and 55 genes, including light-harvesting protein, PSII protein, heat shock protein (i.e. HSP70 and HSP90), and ubiquitin-related genes, overlapped between the treatment groups. Previous studies have indicated that high temperature treatments reduce the efficiency of photochemical reactions by damaging several photosynthetic proteins, including the light-harvesting complexes and PSII proteins, in cultured Symbiodinium strains (OTcH-1 and CS-73) (Takahashi et al., 2008) and symbiotic dinoflagellates in corals such as A. aspera (Gierz et al., 2016;Warner et al., 1999) and Pocillopora spp. (McGinley et al., 2012). In addition, our previous study demonstrated the up-regulation of HSP70 and HSP90 in symbiotic dinoflagellates after 7 d of exposure to 20 and 200 ng/L Irgarol, which are ecologically relevant concentrations in tropical to subtropical coastal seawaters. Furthermore, the ΔF/F m ′ ratio was reduced in symbiotic dinoflagellates exposed to Irgarol at both concentrations (Kamei et al., 2020). Takeuchi et al. (2020) measured delayed fluorescence (DF) of symbiotic dinoflagellates in A. tenuis exposed to 1 μg/L Irgarol for 14 d and monitored the changes in coral colour. They revealed a significant correlation between the fast decay DF component (0.1-10.0 s) and the coral colour. The fast decay DF component was considered to be composed of the charge recombination between P680 and the primary (Q A ) or secondary (Q B ) quinone acceptors (Katsumata and Takeuchi, 2017). Thus, Takeuchi et al. (2020) indicated that coral bleaching is caused by compromising the electron accumulation functions of quinones Q A and Q B in photosystem II. These results suggest that Irgarol exposure disrupts gene expression of several photosynthetic proteins, including the light-harvesting complexes, PSII proteins, and HSPs.

The GO and KEGG pathway enrichment analyses were performed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying the bleaching effect of Irgarol on the corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates. Although Irgarol affected comparatively similar GO terms in both corals and The pathways indicated in bold font are those in the protein-protein interaction network (Figs. 5 and S2). symbiotic dinoflagellates, the KEGG pathway analysis showed that the transcriptional responses of coral and dinoflagellates to Irgarol exposure were distinct from one another. For example, the TGF-β signalling pathway in coral was significantly enriched under the 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol treatments, whereas other KEGG pathways in coral, such as oxidative phosphorylation, the metabolic pathway, adherens junction, and apoptosis, were significantly enriched only under the 10 μg/L Irgarol treatment. In contrast, the KEGG pathway and/or the protein interaction network analyses in symbiotic dinoflagellates showed that both 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol treatments commonly affected carbon fixation in photosynthetic organisms, metabolic pathways, photosynthesis, and protein processing in the endoplasmic reticulum. These distinct patterns in the KEGG pathways may be related to the differences in the actual exposure concentrations experienced and bleaching efficiencies of Irgarol between corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates. Although a previous study demonstrated host cell apoptosis, which is the function affected by elevated temperature-induced bleaching (Oakley and Davy, 2018), our results indicate that PSII herbicide-induced bleaching affected the expression of a wide range of genes belonging to a variety of pathways in coral and symbiotic flagellates.

Our previous study showed that 7 d of exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol significantly down-regulated the expression of A. tenuis HSP90 by 0.56-fold under the 1 μg/L treatment and 0.48-fold under the 10 μg/L treatment (Ishibashi et al., 2018). However, the expression of this gene did not reach our defined significance threshold of <1/3 for the gene expression ratio of the exposed to control groups in the present study, and therefore, A. tenuis HSP90 did not appear in our DEG lists. In contrast, we previously reported the up-regulation of HSP70 and HSP90 in symbiotic dinoflagellates exposed to 20 and 200 ng/L Irgarol for 7 d (Kamei et al., 2020). Moreover, the RNA-Seq analysis in the present study revealed a significant up-regulation of Symbiodinium HSP70 and HSP90 under the 1 μg/L Irgarol treatment; however, these genes were down-regulated under the 10 μg/L Irgarol treatment. These results suggest that Symbiodinium HSP70 and HSP90 are differentially expressed in response to Irgarol exposure and that their expression patterns are more complex than that of A. tenuis HSP90. Further studies are necessary to clarify the functional roles of Symbiodinium HSP70 and HSP90 in response to Irgarol exposure.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In the present study, we clarified the bleaching effects of 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol on the body colour of corals. Moreover, we detected approximately 110-150 DEGs in corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates after the Irgarol treatments. In addition to the effects of Irgarol exposure on the expression of HSPs, which has been described in previous studies, we identified several genes whose expression was altered by Irgarol exposure in coral and symbiotic dinoflagellates: GFP, cry1, chromoprotein, caspase 8, and AmNR7 in corals, and light-harvesting protein, photosystem II protein, HSP, and ubiquitin-related genes in symbiotic dinoflagellates. Furthermore, the bioinformatic analyses using DEGs revealed that Irgarol affected various GO terms and KEGG pathways/protein interaction networks differently in corals compared with those in symbiotic dinoflagellates, suggesting that different molecular mechanisms underlie the bleaching effects of Irgarol in corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates. Our data complement the Irgarol toxicity data at the molecular level, indicating that the bleaching effect might be involved in Irgarol toxicity in both corals and symbiotic dinoflagellates, in addition to inducing host cell apoptosis. Our findings contribute to the elucidation of effects of the new generation of antifouling biocides on the biosphere, hydrosphere, and anthroposphere of coral reef ecosystems, which are essential to tropical coastal regions. Future studies should evaluate whether the transcripts identified in the present study or additional transcripts could serve as biomarkers for sublethal Irgarol exposure, whether transcriptional alterations translate to changes at the protein level in target tissues, and whether the effects of Irgarol persist during chronic exposure.

div.p: This work was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Grants-in-Aid for Scientific Research (KAKENHI) [grant numbers 26281048 and 18H03387]. . Protein-protein interaction network of the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in symbiotic dinoflagellates exposed to 10 μg/L Irgarol for 7 d. Protein interactions were categorised according to their Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway classifications.

div.head: Data statement
div.p: All data needed to evaluate the conclusions presented in the paper are provided in the paper and/or the Supplementary Materials. Additional data related to this paper may be requested from the authors.

div.head: CRediT authorship contribution statement
div.p: Hiroshi Ishibashi: Conceptualization, Data curation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Methodology, Software, Writingoriginal draft, Writingreview & editing. Daisuke Takaichi: Conceptualization, Data curation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Methodology, Software, Writingoriginal draft. Ichiro Takeuchi: Conceptualization, Funding acquisition, Methodology, Project administration, Validation, Visualization, Writingoriginal draft, Writingreview & editing.

div.head: Declaration of competing interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

div.head: Appendix A. Supplementary data
div.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2021.146542.
